title: Before 1 July 2017, will China fire a missile that lands within 50 nautical miles of Taiwan?
preds: Timescale is too short to be very likely.
China, U.S. agree on aim of 'complete, irreversible' Korean denuclearization
I think it's very unlikely that China would risk that kind of provocation towards the US at this point in time.
Going to zero because I don't think China wants to rock the proverbial boat right now.
No rocking the boat before Communist Party meeting.
While it's certainly possible this could happen at any time, July 1st seems a little soon.

There have been three Taiwanese Strait Crises and the first two were in the 1950s.  The above mentioned Taiwanese Strait Crisis took place in a very different world.  The most recent firing of any missile in the Taiwan Strait was the Hsiung Feng III missile mishap in 2016 when a Chinese Navy vessel accidentally struck a Taiwanese fishing boat with a missile during Chinese Navy training.  In today's world, especially in that region, firing a missile in the Taiwan Strait would have to be caused by another accident and accidental missile firings from a well trained navy are rare.
Will say it was a test fire over the air space then there was complications with the system if there's a detination or not is the question also maybe the same situation with Japan

China/US (Taiwan) relations stable as at May 2017.  China focussed on NKorea.  Do not see that China would risk stable relations for highly provocative act of firing a missle that lands withing 50nm of Taiwan.

Testing or firing a missile in the region at the moment would be a highly illogical decision for China to make considering the current tensions in the region around the situation in the Korean Peninsula. While Chinese President Xi has met with US President Trump, the reality is that the US-Sino relationship remains ultimately tense. The sharp anti-DPRK rhetoric that the US has engaged in does affect the way China acts - they continue to seek the status quo. missile firing on Taiwan risks nothing more than escalating an already tense region closer to conflict.
No importants events and updates recently
Government of China is more focused in economic and social stability and the new Taiwan President has not been evocative

The Chinese tested a missile in waters close to North Korea two days ago. The Chinese ship’s missile systems are being tested in the Yellow Sea – which separates China from the Korean peninsular. This all comes after China warned the world that “storm is about to break” on the Korean peninsula.
0pc too low given the volatility in this area.

Doesn't seem to be much action in Taiwan over independence lately and therefore China is not likely to react to anything.  And, it is less likely for something offensive as this to happen (at least) before the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party of China this fall which occurs just once every five years.
China has no good reason to risk its two largest trading partners, the EU and the US over Taiwan, regardless how politically important it sees the island.

China live-fires aircraft carrier group amid Taiwan tensions with US 
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/16/china-live-fires-aircraft-carrier-group-amid-taiwan-tensions-with-us
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

While extremely unlikely as it is an unlikely successful strategy for China, tensions have increased over the last 6 months.  So a very very slim chance that there is a continued escalation to the point of a warning missile.
China is not militarizing South China Sea, Premier Li says
Taiwan Launches Homegrown Submarine Program to Counter China

While the Taiwan strait is always tense, my impression is that things aren't serious enough of missiles. While tensions between China and Taiwan have increased following the election of a more pro-independence candidate, I haven't yet seen signs of Beijing opting for shows of military force.
There are other ways for the PRC to make this point.  They won't start flinging missile about until they have a clearer idea of what Mr. Tangerine Man will do.  Good luck with that, PRC.

The South China Sea is a high contentious area.  Launching a missile in the vicinity of Taiwan would not only trigger international crises, it would not be in the interest of China to do so.  With the new US administration suggesting more autonomy for military operations in the APAC region, I can conclude that China is unlikely to 'stir the pot' until a clear US foreign policy is established by the Trump administration.  Even in an obscure scenario where disruption to the One China Policy is endangered with a shift in US-Taiwan relations, China's foreign policy often condemns direct military or confrontational activity.
Such a radical step could proceed only from  some provocation from TAIWAN WHICH IS HIGHLY UNLIKELY in the near future.

I think China is still assessing its position relative to a Trump administration. (Where should they throw their influence? Where should they pull the punches, and not  demand too much?)  Aggressive military-ish displays is more incendiary than anything. To fire a rocket at Taiwan will cost Beijing a sizable amount of political capital, for nothing gained and at the risk of bringing its maritime conflicts to a boil.
Controversy over South China Sea will cause China to escalate their maritime activity.
Bellicose and need to learn their lesson.
See no reason for that kind of direct provocation
China does not need to show dominence. It would provoke unnecessary ire, to no advantage.
China has little strategic interest in such a message.
enough time for something out of the blue to happen that could trigger it

Why would they do something like that? There's nothing to gain from such an action. Adding to that the current White House occupant reputation for unpredictability, and what has China to gain? Chinese are more rational than that.
That would be a very big provocation at this time. China has already seen that they can work with Trump (one China policy) without resorting to missiles.
Doesn't seem likely given Trump and Tillerson backing off their comments about S. China sea and recognition of one China policy.

This event is highly unlikely.  However, given the policy instability and the institutionalization of foreign policy and its direction by this administration, the consensus in the international community remains support of the 1 China policy.
If they do this, they will claim it was an accident.  It won't be.   It will be another test of President Littlefingers.

China aircraft carrier crosses Taiwan Strait amid tension
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-38579559
USA influence in this region is less
